A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as any other. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences and may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there are not sufficient space available to answer the questions.

Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Provincial Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Harriet Turner
2. Your address: Kipling, Sask., S.S.S.R.
3. Date: July 1st, 1954
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Newton Heath, (now) Manchester
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Joseph Barlow, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year): January 1897
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Stockport, England; Before 1897
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.):
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My two brothers had moved to Canada and they reported good prospects in the farming industry.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    We learned about the West through my brothers who had been farming in Canada for about five years.

Kip Line, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please explain further. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Harriet Turner
2. Your address: Kip Line, Sask.
3. Date: July 1st, 1954
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Newton Heath, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? (Give month and year): Joseph Barlow, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): January 1897
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan:
   Stockport, England
   Bradford, England
   Hope, Canada
   Winnipeg, Canada
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.):
   Nine feet tall
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My two brothers have moved to Canada and they reported good prospects in the farming industry.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information)?
    We learned about the West through my mother who had been living in Canada for about five years.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were very anxious to see someone to the west. We had to travel by ourselves or with a party (family, friends or other group).

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train from Valdosta to Whitehorse.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other occurrences, etc.)

The trip was very pleasant. We were 15 days on the trail. I was very sick when we got there because my infant daughter was very young.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Regina (approximately 100 miles)

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled at Regina.

17. How long have you lived since coming to Saskatchewan?

We have lived here for about 10 years.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

Working on a farm in England.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were very anxious to come.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I traveled with my husband and baby daughter.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train from Winnipeg to Halifax.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, interesting sights, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

The trip was very pleasant. We were 15 days on the boat. It was very nice and the captain was very good to my infant daughter. She had a big time and was very active and mischievous.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Regina (Farmers' Hotel)

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled at Okotoks.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

I worked on a farm in England.

(a) A housewife on a farm

(b) Great mistress of the farm

(c) In 33 years of residence I have been a faithful worker, from my childhood until death
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to settle here? If so, state their names and the place to settle.

Yes. My Husband & His Family.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Just after we settled here in 1897, my Youngest Son came to live with us in England. In 1921 my eldest sister came to visit me & after returned to England.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

None.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Just went about once a week in the wagon to visit our neighbors & about 4 times a year in a wagon to do our shopping in Willard & market our crops in Butler.

Just after we settled here in 1897 my young folks came to see me in England. In 1921 my eldest son came to see me & after returned to England to stay.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About 15 letters to England and one year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Date: Morehouse Joseph, 7/4/1895
Place: Geauga County, Ohio

21. Did anyone else come to Shaker Heights before or after your family?

Yes, my husband's brother W. A. Turner & his family.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Just after we settled here, May 1893, my younger sister came to Kentucky, then returned to England. In 1921 my oldest aunt came to visit me & also returned to England.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

None.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Just went about once a week in the wagon to visit our neighbors & about 4 times a year in a wagon to do our shopping in Willoughby & market and everything further.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else settle here? Yes, my husband's brother W. A. Turner & his family.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

When we came to Saskatchewan first it was with the idea to stay permanently. We came to turn (garden path runners).

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

When we came to Saskatchewan it was with the idea of trying permanently. We came to plant a grain farm (planned).
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What, where did they have for months?

The district was thinly settled.

No known or precise number away prior to 1914.

35. Did many people move during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes. None of them returned.
